Sheet1.name: Jol Thoms
Sheet1.title: Radio Amnion
Sheet1.description: RADIO AMNION: SONIC TRANSMISSIONS OF CARE IN OCEANIC SPACE is a multi-year sound art project for the waters of Earth, commissioning and relaying new compositions by contemporary artists more than 2kms deep with/in the Pacific Ocean. During each full moon, far beyond human perception, the abyssal waters of Cascadia Basin resonate with the deep frequencies and voices of invited artists. All transmissions are relayed in the sea through a submerged neutrino telescope experiment’s calibration system and available here online only during the three days of each full moon. Register to be notified for our next transmissions.

Sheet1.name: M. Koetter, J. Tolva
Sheet1.title: The Aeolian Interface Project
Sheet1.description: Research with the initial vision was to control digital instruments through gestures, much like a conductor, leading to the idea of creating a MIDI version of the Æolian harp—a wind-activated instrument. This concept sought to bridge nature and technology, echoing Heidegger's views on technology as a mode of revealing, allowing the wind's inherent patterns to become audibly evident. However, technical limitations prevented precise detection of the harp strings' vibrations by wind, resulting in a redesigned installation that combined elements of sculpture, wind vane, wind chime, and equipment rack to capture wind patterns.

Sheet1.name: Brian Eno
Sheet1.title: THE FUTURE WILL BE LIKE PERFUME
Sheet1.description: Eno recounts a deep fascination with the elusive world of scent, beginning from art college days to discovering ancient aromatic substances in old pharmacies. Despite attempts at concocting unique fragrances and understanding their intricacies, they find that the realm of smell lacks a definitive language for precise description, much like the challenges in describing modern sound in classical musical terms. This exploration of scent parallels their experiences in sound recording, highlighting the complexities and mysteries of both worlds.

Sheet1.name: Takashi Kokubo
Sheet1.title: Barcelona  Gaudi’s Dream
Sheet1.description: Takashi Kokubo (小久保隆) released ten albums over the course of 1992-93 in what is called the "Ion Series". These ten albums were released in two five-album sub-series, one in 1992 and one in 1993. The first sub-series, released in 1992, is titled 「都市生活者へ送る音風景」 or "Sound Scenery for City People". This album is part three of the first sub-series, making it the third album in the Ion Series.

Sheet1.name: Steve Roach
Sheet1.title: Structures from Silence
Sheet1.description: Released in 1984, Structures From Silence remains an iconic American release in the ambient and electronic genres. It’s a well-respected soundtrack for contemplation, relaxation, meditation, and focused creativity. The album continues to appear at the top of charts and is mentioned as one of the best releases in the genre; even more importantly, it is a meaningful touchstone for thousands upon thousands of listeners who have lived many years within its nurturing embrace. The album has endured, growing more potent over time, especially in the accelerated pace of today’s life. Emotional, powerful, and enriching, it is a living example of the true healing quality that music can hold.

Sheet1.name: Brian Eno
Sheet1.title: Ambient 4: On Land
Sheet1.description: Ambient 4: On Land is the eighth solo studio album by Brian Eno, released in March 1982 by EG Records. It was the final edition in Eno's ambient series, which began in 1978 with the release of Ambient 1: Music for Airports.

Sheet1.name: African Head Charge
Sheet1.title: My Life In A Hole In The Ground
Sheet1.description:
The groundbreaking debut album from 1981 that plays on both the title and concept of David Byrne and Brian Eno's My Life in the Bush of Ghosts.

Built upon sparse backing tracks constructed by Adrian Sherwood, the producer invited Bonjo Iyabinghi Noah (who had studied under Count Ossie in the rasta drumming camp at Wareika Hill in Jamaica) to lay down hand percussion patterns and breaks on top, augmented by stereo-strafed effects and the occasional burst of Sun Ra-style horns. The result is a unique mixture of traditional African rhythms, dub and free jazz.

Features DJ favourite “Stebeni’s Theme” and “Far Away Chant”, used to famously gruesome effect by David Lynch in the film Wild At Heart.
credits

Sheet1.name: Sun Ra
Sheet1.title: A Joyful Noise
Sheet1.description: Renowned documentary film director Robert Mugge decided to spend three years peering into the life of the colorful Sun Ra and his rowdy band mates. One reviewer wrote of the underappreciated and relatively unknown 1980 film, Sun Ra: A Joyful Noise, that it was not only “a performance film, but also as a record of the famous composer, keyboardist, bandleader’s purposely odd personal and professional life.”

Sheet1.name: Laurie Spiegel
Sheet1.title: The Expanding Universe
Sheet1.description: In 1977, electronic composer Laurie Spiegel's "Kepler's Harmony of the Worlds" traveled to the edge of the solar system as part of Voyager 1 and 2's "Golden Record".

Sheet1.name: Laraaji
Sheet1.title: Ambient 3: Day of Radiance
Sheet1.description: Laraaji’s glistening album “Ambient 3: Day of Radiance” has from the beginning been considered an outlier. Though widely celebrated at the time of its release in 1980 -- as the third installment of Brian Eno’s emerging ambient music series (Ambient 1-4) -- the album also brought with it an aura of mystification. Where did it fit in? An uncharted synthesis of resonating zither textures, interlocking, hammered rhythms and 3-D sound treatments (courtesy of Eno) “Day of Radiance” seemed to push open many doors at once, ambient music being only one of them.

Sheet1.name: Derek Bailey
Sheet1.title: Improvisation
Sheet1.description: A book to deal with the nature of improvisation in all its forms--Indian music, flamenco, baroque, organ music, rock, jazz, contemporary, and "free" music

Sheet1.name: Dave Vorhaus
Sheet1.title: Sea of Tranquility
Sheet1.description: Music video with footage paired from Assignment: Outerspace (1960)

Sheet1.name: Pharoah Sanders
Sheet1.title: Journey to the One
Sheet1.description: Journey to the One is a double album led by saxophonist Pharoah Sanders recorded in 1979 and released on the Theresa label.

Sheet1.name: Robert Ashley
Sheet1.title: Automatic Writing
Sheet1.description: "On Automatic Writing, Robert Ashley composes under the influence of his 'involuntary speech.' (In his liner notes, Ashley revealed that he suffered from 'a mild form of Tourette's.') The piece starts quietly, with scraps of Ashley's mild, tremulous voice arranged next to more fluid French translations and barely-there touches of Moog. After Ashley's phrases lengthen enough to encompass sense-making phrases, a bass-register groove briefly appears, vanishes, then returns. Few pieces so quiet have proven as captivating; many that intend to be equally startling can't capture Ashley's range of surprises.” -- Seth Colter Walls, from Pitchfork's "Fifty Best Ambient Albums of All Time"

Sheet1.name: Valerie Wilmer
Sheet1.title: As Serious As Your Life
Sheet1.description: In this classic account of the new black music of the 1960s and 70s, celebrated photographer and jazz historian Val Wilmer tells the story of how a generation of revolutionary musicians established black music as the true vanguard of American culture.

Sheet1.name: Mind Body Spirit Festival
Sheet1.title: Mind Body Spirit Festival
Sheet1.description: The Mind Body Spirit Festival is a festival that first took place at the Olympia Exhibition Centre in London in 1977.

Sheet1.name: Ashra
Sheet1.title: New Age of Earth
Sheet1.description: 1976 album from Ashra

Sheet1.name: Stuart Marshall
Sheet1.title: Alvin Lucier's Music of Signs In Space
Sheet1.description: Article describing Alvin Lucier

Sheet1.name: Theodor Schwenk
Sheet1.title: Sensitive Chaos
Sheet1.description: Text describing formations through water.

Sheet1.name: Brian Eno
Sheet1.title: Another Green World Documentary
Sheet1.description: Brian Eno Film - 1975

Sheet1.name: Robert Fripp & Brian Eno
Sheet1.title: Evening Star
Sheet1.description: Album from Robert Fripp and Brian Eno

Sheet1.name: Iasos
Sheet1.title: Inter-Dimensional Music
Sheet1.description: This is the album that began the genre of "New Age" Music in 1975, along with Steven Halpern's "Spectrum Suite". This is a compilation of Iasos' earliest works, and provides an excellent variety of interesting music for focused listening. This CD includes all the selections on the original LP, plus the bonus track "Angel Play".

Sheet1.name: Suzanne Ciani
Sheet1.title: Buchla Concerts 1975
Sheet1.description: These “concerts” are the epitome of rare music technology historic documents, performed by a real musician whose skills and academic education in classical composition already outweighed her male synthesiser contemporaries of twice her age. At the very start of her fragile career these recordings are nothing short of sacrificial ode to her mentor and machine, sonic pickets of the revolution and love letters to an absolutely genuine vision of and ‘alternative’ musical future. In denouncing her own precocious polymathmatic past in a bid to persuade the world to sing from a new hymn sheet, Suzanne Ciani created a bi-product of never before heard music that would render the pigeon holes “ambient” and “futuristic” utterly inadequate. Providing nothing short of an entirely different feminine take on the experimental “records” of Morton Subotnick and proving to a small, judgmental audience and jury the true versatility of one of the most radical and idiosyncratic musical instruments of the 20th century. These recordings have not been heard since then.

Sheet1.name: Donna Summer & Giorgio Moroder
Sheet1.title: Love To Love You Baby
Sheet1.description: Original long version 1975, vocalist D. Summer, electronic music, Giorgio Moroder.

Sheet1.name: David Topp and Max Eastley
Sheet1.title: New and Rediscovered Musical Instruments
Sheet1.description: Pictures from an unofficial reprint of David Toop's fondamental 1974 book on British instrument builders, published on his own Quartz/Mirliton imprint.

Sheet1.name: Charlemagne Palestine
Sheet1.title: Four Manifestations on Six Elements
Sheet1.description: Album from Charlemagne Palestine

Sheet1.name: Pauline Oliveros
Sheet1.title: Sonic Meditations
Sheet1.description: Article describing Oliveros practice in sonic meditations.

Sheet1.name: Sun Ra
Sheet1.title: Sun Ra and his Intergalactic Arkestra - Live Jazz Session
Sheet1.description: Black & white video captured in France on 1-8-72 on their way back to Oakland after the 1971 Euro/Egypt tour.

Sheet1.name: John Coney
Sheet1.title: Sun Ra - Space is the Place
Sheet1.description: Space Is the Place is an 85-minute Afrofuturist science fiction film made in 1972 and released in 1974. It was directed by John Coney, written by Sun Ra and Joshua Smith, and features Sun Ra and his Arkestra. During the late-1960s and early-1970s, Sun Ra and his ensemble made several forays to California. In 1971, Sun Ra taught a course, "The Black Man in the Cosmos", at University of California, Berkeley. Over the course of these California visits, Sun Ra came to the attention of Jim Newman, who produced the film Space Is the Place starring Sun Ra and his Arkestra, and based, in part, on Sun Ra's Berkeley lectures.

Sheet1.name: Alice Coltrane & Carlos Santana
Sheet1.title: Illuminations
Sheet1.description: Label: Columbia / Year: 1974

Sheet1.name: Basil Kirchin
Sheet1.title: World Within Worlds
Sheet1.description: 1974 Album exploring ambience and field recordings.

Sheet1.name: Stephen Hill
Sheet1.title: Hearts of Space
Sheet1.description: Hearts of Space is an American weekly syndicated public radio show[4] featuring music of a contemplative nature[5] drawn largely from the ambient, new-age and electronic genres, while also including classical, world, Celtic, experimental, and other music selections.[6][7][8] For many years, the show's producer and presenter, Stephen Hill, has applied the term "space music" to the music broadcast on the show, irrespective of genre.[9] It is the longest-running radio program of its type in the world. Each episode ends with Hill gently saying, "Safe journeys, space fans ... wherever you are."

Sheet1.name: Klaus Wachsmann
Sheet1.title: Spencer to Hood: A Changing View of Non-European Music
Sheet1.description: Paper exploring the shift of western music.

Sheet1.name: Henry Wolff & Nancy Hennings
Sheet1.title: Tibetan Bells

Sheet1.name: Terry Riley
Sheet1.title: Persian Surgery Dervishes
Sheet1.description: Persian Surgery Dervishes is a recording of two live solo electric organ concerts, the first held in Los Angeles on 18 April 1971 and the second in Paris on 24 May 1972, by avant-garde minimalist composer Terry Riley, following his A Rainbow in Curved Air and In C. The two very different performances of the same composition "Persian Surgery Dervishes" are meant to show the importance of improvisation in Riley's music. Riley plays a modified Yamaha electric organ tuned in just intonation.

Sheet1.name: Pauline Oliveros
Sheet1.title: Sonic Meditations
Sheet1.description: Book describing meditations on sound and sound walks.

Sheet1.name: Dr. Roger Payne
Sheet1.title: Songs of the Humpback Whale
Sheet1.description: Legendary album which was one of the first mass manufactured albums to record non-humans.

Sheet1.name: BBC
Sheet1.title: Introducing the MOOG SYNTHESISER
Sheet1.description: Description of the possibilites of new Moog synthesizer, and how it can be expanded to further music.

Sheet1.name: Frederic Rzewski
Sheet1.title: The People United Will Never Be Defeated!
Sheet1.description:
The People United is a set of 36 variations on the Chilean song "¡El pueblo unido jamás será vencido!" by Sergio Ortega and Quilapayún.
The song on which the variations is based is one of many that emerged from the Unidad Popular coalition in Chile between 1969 and 1973, prior to the overthrow of the Salvador Allende government. Rzewski composed the variations in September and October 1975, as a tribute to the struggle of the Chilean people against the newly imposed repressive regime of Augusto Pinochet; indeed the work contains allusions to other leftist struggles of the same and immediately preceding time, such as quotations from the Italian traditional socialist song "Bandiera Rossa" and the Bertolt Brecht-Hanns Eisler "Solidarity Song."

In general, the variations are short, and build up to climaxes of considerable force. The 36 variations, following the 36 bars of the tune, are in six groups of six. The pianist, in addition to needing a virtuoso technique, is required to whistle, slam the piano lid, and catch the after-vibrations of a loud attack as harmonics: all of these are "extended" techniques in 20th-century piano writing. Much of the work uses the language of 19th-century romanticism, but mixes this language with pandiatonic tonality, modal writing, and even serial techniques.

As in the Goldberg Variations by Johann Sebastian Bach, the final variation is a direct restatement of the original theme, intended to be heard with new significance after the long journey through the variations.

Sheet1.name: Buckminster Fuller
Sheet1.title: Operating Manual For Spaceship Earth
Sheet1.description: In this accessible volume, first published in 1969, Fuller offers advice on how to guide "spaceship earth" toward a sustainable future.

Sheet1.name: Thomas Sebok
Sheet1.title: Zoosemiotics
Sheet1.description: Description of the term Zoosemiotics, and animal communication.

Sheet1.title: Cymatics
Sheet1.description: Cymatics is the study of sound-wave phenomena. This text vividly depicts the significance of audible sound throughout our world.

Sheet1.name: John Cage

Sheet1.name: John C. Lilly
Sheet1.title: John C. Lilly - The Scientist - Subtitled
Sheet1.description: Interview on dolphin communication.

Sheet1.name: La Monte Young
Sheet1.title: Composition 1960 #7
Sheet1.description: With 4’33” Cage paved the way for works such as Young’s Composition 1960 pieces, which provide one of the basic foundations for the idea to serve as the artwork by itself, with no unnecessary embellishments. Central to Young’s work is the concept of “stasis,” as opposed to “Fluxus.” “Change or flux is inevitable,” Young wrote. “Stasis, or remaining the same, is impossible. Therefore, to achieve the static state is the goal, while the state of flux, variation, or contrast, is unavoidable and thus unnecessary as a goal.” Later, Composition 1960 pieces appeared alongside works by other artists in An Anthology (1963), edited by Young, a publication characterized as “chance operations, concept art, anti art, indeterminacy, . . . improvisation, meaningless work,” and “natural disasters.” In 1960 and 1961, together with Yoko Ono, Young organized a series of events at Ono’s loft on Chambers Street that had a germinative effect on the formation of Fluxus.

Sheet1.name: La Monte Young
Sheet1.title: Composition 6
Sheet1.description: 1 hour version of La Monte Young's Composition 1960 No.7

Sheet1.name: John Cage
Sheet1.title: 4'33" (In Proportional Notation)
Sheet1.description: 4'33" (In Proportional Notation) is one of three versions of the score for Cage’s “silent piece,” a musical composition first performed by the pianist David Tudor in Woodstock, New York, in 1952. While the lost original score used conventional musical notation to signify three periods of silence, this version is composed of a series of vertical lines that visually represent the duration of four minutes and thirty-three seconds of silence.

Sheet1.name: Harry Partch
Sheet1.title: Genesis of a Music
Sheet1.description: Genesis of a Music is a book first published in 1949 by microtonal composer Harry Partch. Partch first presents a polemic against both equal temperament and the long history of stagnation in the teaching of music.

Sheet1.name: Colin McPhee
Sheet1.title: A House in Bali
Sheet1.description: Published in 1947, A House in Bali by Colin McPhee remains today a relevant and engaging book for readers looking to learn about the intricacies and history of Balinese culture generally, and music specifically.

Sheet1.name: University of Chicago
Sheet1.title: Sounds from Tomorrow's World: Sun Ra and the Chicago Years, 1946-1961
Sheet1.description: Sounds from Tomorrow’s World: Sun Ra and the Chicago Years 1946-1961 is an extension of a 2009-10 Regenstein Library exhibit curated by Andrew Rea entitled Sun Ra: ‘My Story Is Mystery.’ It has been curated by Andrew Rea and designed by Kerri Sancomb. Assistance was provided by Daniel Meyer, David Pavelich and Deborah Gillaspie. This exhibit would not have been possible without the scholarly work of Robert L. Campbell, John Corbett, and Harmut Geerken and Christopher Trent.

Sheet1.name: John Cage
Sheet1.title: Sonatas and Interludes for Prepared Piano
Sheet1.description: John Cage  Sonatas and Interludes for Prepared Piano ((1946-1948)) Boris Berman

Sheet1.name: Cotton Club
Sheet1.title: Cotton Clubnightclub, New York City, New York, United States
Sheet1.description: Cotton Club, legendary nightspot in the Harlem district of New York City that for years featured prominent Black entertainers who performed for white audiences. The club served as the springboard to fame for Duke Ellington, Cab Calloway, and many others.

Sheet1.name: Furniture Music
Sheet1.title: Eric Satie
Sheet1.description: Describes a concept of music, a precursor to ambient music.

Sheet1.name: Cabaret Voltaire
Sheet1.title: Dada and Cabaret Voltaire
Sheet1.description: Cabaret Voltaire. Under this name a group of young artists and writers has been formed whose aim is to create a centre for artistic entertainment. The idea of the cabaret will be that guest artists will come and give musical performances and readings at the daily meetings. The young artists of Zurich, whatever their orientation, are invited to come along with suggestions and contributions of all kinds.

Sheet1.name: Luigi Russolo
Sheet1.title: The Art of Noise
Sheet1.description: Manifesto on Noise

Sheet1.name: Erik Satie
Sheet1.title: Vexations
Sheet1.description:
Vexations is a musical work by Erik Satie. Apparently conceived for keyboard (although the single page of manuscript does not specify an instrument), it consists of a short theme in the bass whose four presentations are heard alternatingly unaccompanied and played with chords above. The theme and its accompanying chords are written using enharmonic notation. The piece is undated, but scholars usually assign a date around 1893–1894 on the basis of musical and biographical evidence.
The piece bears the inscription "In order to play the motif 840 times in succession, it would be advisable to prepare oneself beforehand, and in the deepest silence, by serious immobilities." ("Pour se jouer 840 fois de suite ce motif, il sera bon de se préparer au préalable, et dans le plus grand silence, par des immobilités sérieuses.") From the 1960s onward, this text has mostly been interpreted as an instruction that the page of music should be played 840 times,[1][2] although this may not have been Satie's intention.

Sheet1.name: Claude Debussy
Sheet1.title: Letters of Claude Debussy written from Bichain
Sheet1.description: Collection of letters from Claude Debussy.

Sheet1.name: Ernst Chladni
Sheet1.title: Chladni Figures
Sheet1.description: In 1787, German physicist and musician Ernst Chladni published a technique to visualize the modes of vibration of a rigid surface.

Sheet1.name: Suikinkutsu
Sheet1.title: Suikinkutsu
Sheet1.description: A suikinkutsu (水琴窟, literally "water piano cave" in original Chinese or "water zither cave" in Japanese) is a type of Japanese garden ornament and music device. It consists of an upside down buried pot with a hole at the top. Water drips through the hole at the top onto a small pool of water inside of the pot, creating a pleasant splashing sound that rings inside of the pot similar to a bell or Japanese zither. It is usually built next to a traditional Japanese stone basin called chōzubachi, part of a tsukubai for washing hands before the Japanese tea ceremony.
